title: Marko Csollich
text:
Marko Csollich (Marko <a href="%C4%8Coli%C4%87">Čolić</a>) also spelled Markus Freiherr von Csollich (15 April 1766 14 September 1844) was a senior general in the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Army">Austrian Imperial Army</a> with the rank of <a href="feldzeugmeister">feldzeugmeister</a>. His brother <a href="Pavao%20Csollich">Pavao Csollich</a> (1768-1838) was a general, vice marshal and commander in <a href="Vara%C5%BEdin%20County">Veliki Varaždin</a>.
Marko Čolić was born in <a href="Privlaka%2C%20Vukovar-Syrmia%20County">Privlaka</a>, <a href="Slavonia">Slavonia</a>, <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a> (now <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>). In 1782 he enrolled in an Austrian cadet school, from where he progressed in rank. From 1793 to 1795 he participated in the battles in <a href="France">France</a> and <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. He was promoted to <a href="captain">captain</a> in 1796, then <a href="major">major</a> in 1801, <a href="lieutenant%20colonel">lieutenant colonel</a> in 1805, and <a href="colonel">colonel</a> in 1809, he was named <a href="chief%20of%20staff">chief of staff</a> of the 6th Army Corps. In the battles of <a href="Battle%20of%20Aspern-Essling">Aspern-Essling</a> and <a href="Battle%20of%20Wagram">Wagram</a> he showed exceptional courage and was consequently awarded the <a href="Knight%27s%20Cross">Knight's Cross</a> of the <a href="Military%20Order%20of%20Maria%20Theresa">Military Order of Maria Theresa</a>, which automatically ennobled him the following year. With the title of baron, he commanded a brigade in 1813. He continued to distinguish himself in battles, namely the <a href="Battle%20of%20Leipzig">Battle of Leipzig</a>, for which he was awarded both the Commander's Cross of the <a href="Order%20of%20Leopold%20%28Austria%29">Order of Leopold</a> and the <a href="Prussian%20Order%20of%20the%20Red%20Eagle">Prussian Order of the Red Eagle</a>. Following the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Paris%20%281815%29">Treaty of Paris</a>, he was transferred to <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Hungary</a> as a <a href="brigadier%20general">brigadier general</a>. In 1826 he was in <a href="Lviv">Lviv</a>, where he was promoted to <a href="vice%20marshal">vice marshal</a>. He then went on to serve in various places, though the last ten years of his life (1834-1844) he was in command of all the forces in <a href="Slavonia">Slavonia</a> and <a href="Srem">Srem</a>. In 1841, he was promoted to <a href="Feldzeugmeister">Feldzeugmeister</a>.
Marko Čolić died in <a href="Petrovaradin">Petrovaradin</a>, <a href="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a>, <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a>, now <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a> on 14 September 1844.
